9A16C92BCA414087B2D4B7086C407AE8.description: I can compare the relationship between galaxies, star clusters, and interplanetary systems.

264F510D61B742BF93E4ED41B624AE5D.description: I can draw conclusions from the H-R diagram to illustrate the life cycle of different mass stars.

D63CE256F420461AAA2E7D2AEC4C3FCF.description: I can create a flowchart showing how gravity is responsible for solar formation.

7FC83DC362434F6F8AF2FF64EA47751B.description: I can investigate the methods and tools used to study the universe.

F4C3E32F7F6F42E7B0F7D7B65D4A7A4B.description: I can understand and describe the Big Bang Theory.

6649145B17A44D02BCF5A9070EFF2932.description: I can provide evidence for the Big Bang Theory.

FDDDEAC469D14939A6332E97C111E4D2.description:
ES.1.1  Construct an explanation detailing how space can be studied by observing all frequencies of the electromagnetic radiation with differentiated telescopes and observational tools.	
ES.1.2 Describe the expanding universe theory, also known as the "Big Bang Theory," based on observed astronomical evidence including: The Doppler Effect, red shift, Hubble's Law, and the cosmic microwave background.	
ES.1.3  Create a diagram, flowchart, or written explanation that details the cooling of energy into protons and early elements, and early elements into superstars and galaxies. Explain the role of gravitational attraction in the formation of stars and galaxies from clouds of these early elements.	
ES.1.5 Illustrate the hierarchical relationship and scales of stars, planetary systems including multiple-star systems, star clusters, galaxies, and galactic groups in the universe.

3022185155C84C668DA92CE13043F50E.description: I can draw conclusions from the H-R diagram to illustrate the life cycle of different mass stars.

8C7EE1ECF954479B8639BA43EB1E6DC6.description: Differentiate between the life cycles of stars of different masses found on the Hertzsprung-Russell Diagram. Differentiate between low, medium (including our sun), and high mass stars by what elements can be produced, and therefore whether or not they can achieve red giant phase or go supernova.

7B3BDCEC863346B3A6634E0803E0FA4E.description: I can construct a flow chart for stellar body formation as according to the Nebular Hypothesis.

22E4991D64904C488E01A28253879D21.description: I can describe the organization of our solar system, including jovian and terrestrial planets, the Oort Cloud, and the Asteroid Belt.

08A1AC56D22B42739782A7B60B0E4490.description: I can describe each type of stellar body based on its properties.

DA3D6144992742F6888BE891695820D6.description: I can interpret and illustrate the Nebular Hypothesis

593D41824FAE4F7FA7D511A3643FF3CD.description: I can assess how Newton and Kepler's Laws determines the movement of objects in our solar system.

40F6E6E530CE417A88779248F784D4C7.description: I can explain how scientific theories have changed over time. (Ptolemy, Copernicus, Brahe, Kepler, and Galileo)

36433A30FED140138FD111AFE77C07BD.description: I can explain the lifespan of the sun as according to the H-R diagram.

C2AB163F53BB4271B90A0F1C9DD8110C.description: I can describe how specific elements are created by our sun.

946B455F2DAF42BDAFC2A8C809D68F62.description: I can explain how the sun and all stars experience nuclear fusion

EF4D1A3DB1FD410A8B6B0EA3F6923071.description: I can describe the properties of the layers of the sun.

9EB7D617C9C940C1A81632FA7E1766A5.description:
ES.2.1 Construct a flowchart with diagrams and descriptions outlining the nebular theory of solar system formation. Include the formation of one or more stars, planetesimals, protoplanets, Jovian and terrestrial planets, and other objects including satellites and small bodies.	
ES.2.3  Develop a model illustrating the layers and life span of the sun. Explain how nuclear fusion in the core produces elements and energy, which are both retained through convection and released to space, including Earth, through radiation. Additionally, elements heavier than iron cannot form in stars, and form only as a result of supernovae.	
ES.2.4  Use mathematical and/or computational representations to demonstrate the motions of the various kinds of objects in our solar system including planets, satellites, comets, and asteroids. Explain that Kepler’s Laws determine the orbits of those objects and know that Kepler’s Laws are a direct consequence of Newton’s Law of Universal Gravitation together with his laws of motion.  	
ES.2.5  Explain how scientific theory changes over time with the introduction of new information and observational data. Use works from ancient Greeks such as Ptolemy, and other astronomers including Copernicus, Brahe, Kepler, and Galileo to demonstrate the effect of observational data and scientific discussion on our understanding of the mechanics and motion of our solar system.

D067202A7815425A8989EFCA4E952DA6.description: I can differentiate between various kinds of objects in the solar system.

9A502419FBE7462EBB3C1C354BE75855.description: Describe the characteristics of the various kinds of objects in the solar system including planets, satellites, comets, asteroids, and protoplanets. Recognize that planets have been identified orbiting stars other than the sun, or exist outside of solar systems orbiting no sun at all. Describe the organization of our solar system including terrestrial and Jovian planets, asteroid belts, and the Oort Cloud.

975912E5BE864EFF84A52CFC35253C0D.description: I can explain how global climate has shifted throughout Earth's history.

6965E44B0AA944B38A44AF5265AA44DA.description: I can differentiate between weather and climate.

FBF8ABB687EE4C91827040DAD374E945.description: I can make accurate predictions of weather conditions for a specific region/city.

2CDABB96EB14437BB32D2FD9FEEA9FA5.description: I can create and analyze a weather station model.

BEC2883C81F84D4990E966639469B8AD.description: I can create an emergency plan for severe storms of all seasons.

C8FF8245EAF64447896CDE5B767EA282.description: I can differentiate the properties of severe and typical weather systems.

BF2895E26CBB4EBA9DDFBA8A910CE65A.description: I can describe the origin, life cycle, and behavior of weather systems.

0A20B71C996946C580FE11511840EFA5.description: I can describe air masses and fronts.

47814F4A0AF34428BE10408EE054F608.description: I can relate cloud formation to temperature, humidity, and air pressure.

EACBAFBDB4C54754BE6E5981124D833F.description: I can describe the behavior of local and global winds and their affecting factors.

B795049E1F2A4979AD516536CCF6B35B.description:
ES.4.4  Create a model to demonstrate how the Coriolis Effect influences the global circulation of the atmosphere. Explain how changes in the circulation of the atmosphere and oceans can create events such as El Niño and La Niña.	
ES.4.6  Differentiate between weather and climate. Examine long term, natural climate change and periods of glaciation as influenced by Milankovitch Cycles due to the gravity of other solar system bodies (obliquity and precession of axis and eccentricity of orbit). Explain how these are different from any short term (less than thousands of years) changes to climate.

15EE31F1D84D40C387A53503356DC41A.description: I can explain how weather relates to temperature, humidity, and pressure.

9669F85AABFB4982B9C70DD94517ACB0.description: Chart and explain the changes in weather as it relates to humidity, air pressure, and temperature. Explain how these factors result in local wind patterns and cloud cover. Explain the origin, life cycle, and behavior of weather systems, especially severe weather. Create an emergency plan for severe storms, both summer and winter.

BE699E23DBB4416291E86A8E38FC7CEA.description: I can examine a method of alternative sustainable energy use.

F89AAF69CB5A487D840FACA42B66A35B.description: I can explain consequences of overuse on limited resources.

0846D1031D7E4B14839376638D518E86.description: I can differentiate between sutainable and nonrenewable resources.

420DBF58EE84440AB9EA69639A31712E.description: I can relate human and natural activities to global climate and temperature changes.

FDAE20B46274472E834F84ABE548E5BA.description: I can explain how humans can change the amounts of free phosphorus and nitrogen in the earth's systems.

49280AC1D2D0479585CB90E8E9721F97.description: I can explain how human activities impact the carbon, water, and oxygen cycles.

BC37F7CD82614BF8804E306938E35FC5.description: I can illustrate the processes of the water, carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus and oxygen cycle throughout Earth's spheres

A3E68DBC32F242DEA9860A0918264B85.description: I can create a model to identify each layer by function and properties of each.

D67CD16126F043008A6B83ECEA8A92CC.description:
ES.3.1  Create flowcharts that show the exchange of carbon and oxygen between the lithosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, and atmosphere, including carbon dioxide and methane. Explain how human activities such as farming and industry, temperature change in oceans, and natural processes such as volcanic eruptions can speed or slow the cycling from reservoirs within the solid earth and oceans into the atmosphere. 	
ES.3.2  Create diagrams and flowcharts that show the cycling between the lithosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, and atmosphere for nitrogen. Complete the same for phosphorus, excluding the atmosphere. Explain how human activities can alter the amounts of both phosphorus and nitrogen between these layers. 	
ES.3.3  Analyze and explain how events on one side of the world can alter temperature and precipitation around the globe. Analyze and explain the possible effects of natural and human-driven processes on our atmosphere and climate.	
ES.3.4  Evaluate the use of sustainable versus nonrenewable resources. Explain the consequences of overuse and continued increased consumption of limited resources. Analyze and evaluate the benefits of researching, designing, and developing sustainable resources for private use and industry.	
ES.4.2  Create models to demonstrate the circulation, retention, and reflection of heat in regards to the atmosphere, solid land, and bodies of water including lakes and oceans. Demonstrate the effects of cities, various terrain, cloud cover, sea ice, and open water on albedo. Examine local and global heat exchanges, including land & sea breezes, lake effects, urban heat islands, and thermohaline circulation.	
ES.4.4  Create a model to demonstrate how the Coriolis Effect influences the global circulation of the atmosphere. Explain how changes in the circulation of the atmosphere and oceans can create events such as El Niño and La Niña.

D6EC35E0F0BD46188763D6ECDA88E228.description: I can examine origin, charcteristics, and function of Earth's atmosphere.

8643DB5968E346F49937E25D8F2CF258.description: Create a model that shows the composition, distribution, and circulation of gases in Earth's atmosphere. Show how carbon and oxygen cycles affect the composition through gas exchange with organisms, oceans, the solid earth, and industry.

5D5B08B1C7374FC5B4E00362D235ADF8.description: I can explain how periods of glaciation are linked to periods of global climate change.

AA3D0203A7F44E5FBCA554B6B914380E.description: I can examine how the Milankovitch Cycles influence periods of glaciation.

71F30593EB074EABB59D6829487E8F76.description: I can compare and contrast continental and valley glaciers.

809529DADE7841D9ADECDC0FD68198D6.description: I can explain what factors drive ocean currents.

955C2964D1B04D63908DBB005918392F.description: I can list the types of currents that flow throughout the ocean.

CDCE6EEAA3F24CD89A7CA21010677B1D.description: I can explain measures to conserve and protect ground water supply.

059A6FE2C1924078A5667E7CC0CDAB61.description: I can demonstrate how surface water affects geological features.

031AF06B450346B183DE9F907F0CC0B1.description: I can list factors that affect the storage and movement of ground water.

09E19FF3324042129EA28342A82EFCC0.description:
ES.4.2  Create models to demonstrate the circulation, retention, and reflection of heat in regards to the atmosphere, solid land, and bodies of water including lakes and oceans. Demonstrate the effects of cities, various terrain, cloud cover, sea ice, and open water on albedo. Examine local and global heat exchanges, including land & sea breezes, lake effects, urban heat islands, and thermohaline circulation.	
"
ES.5.3  Construct a model that demonstrates the difference between weathering, erosion, transportation of material, deposition, and new soil and sedimentary rock formation. Differentiate between types of physical and chemical weathering."	
ES.4.6  Differentiate between weather and climate. Examine long term, natural climate change and periods of glaciation as influenced by Milankovitch Cycles due to the gravity of other solar system bodies (obliquity and precession of axis and eccentricity of orbit). Explain how these are different from any short term (less than thousands of years) changes to climate.

ECA33022A066443D9C69F8DCC186D046.description: I can illustrate the movement of water through the water cycle with a model.

814AC7AEF74B4E41BB3B3708634E1ED4.description: Create a presentation that demonstrates the process of the water cycle on both local and global scales. Illustrate the process of water cycling both from the solid earth to the atmosphere and around the solid earth. Examine the interaction of ground water, surface water, and ocean circulation. Illustrate the effects of human activity on water systems.

04D1D117A38449AE96EA4D26E55E38EC.description: I can create an action plan for earthquake preparation.

8A38F42E22904043AB24C27677F03DBD.description: Create an action plan detailing what to do in an emergency if an earthquake occurred near the school or home. Detail what should be kept in an earthquake preparation kit, how to prepare homes for earthquake safety, and what actions should be taken during and after an earthquake to ensure personal safety.

848BE5CDBBA94F109B858494ACB128ED.description: I can describe common hazards associated with earthquakes.

9221B6FDBF144B25BF904A245BED2E1D.description: I can compare and contrast body and surface seismic waves.

DF823358DDB347179D4BB15F5344FA77.description: I can explain how the Wabash Valley Fault system is related to intraplate fault zones.

B6B82E1446754328863BA189BC609B16.description: I can differentiate between intraplate faults and plate boundaries.

26FBA47360A04963B9FCBEFA06F0B5E9.description: I can describe the relationship between an earthquake and a tsunami.

2950382401D24F6CBB8FDD9C624F2DC3.description: I can explain how tectonic earthquakes are created by tectonic motion

7CDC119328274C01A7A9D3EEA4756E9E.description: Use models, diagrams, and captions to explain how tectonic motion creates earthquakes and tsunamis. Using resources such as indianamap.org, analyze how close the school is to known faults and liquefaction potential. Differentiate between intraplate fault zones such as the Wabash Valley Fault System and the more commonly discussed faults along tectonic margins.

76CCB71282F64CDFB2D8BC8C41F46DE0.description: I can create a gradient of destruction for types of volcanoes based on viscosity and chemical composition of lava.

03DA9DC20F08478C9CD6D76FBE093323.description: I can relate magma viscosity to the types of lava and volcano shape.

FDF6795F4B3E4DC3A6A1E8516B02ACB9.description: I can relate chemical composition and geographical location to volcano formation.

F853A47987A0494ABF4EB2F563925293.description: I can differentiate formation processes and types of eruptions of shield, composite, and cinder cone volcanoes.

C40953EDD26B429C997E6E926F23EFCD.description: Create models and differentiate between shield, composite, and cinder cone volcanoes. Explain how volcanoes form, how the chemical composition of lava affects the type of volcanoes formed, and how the location (such as hot spots or along continental or oceanic margins) can affect the types of magma present.

C7C91D2D5748452B8440E280742BF4B6.description: I can define and provide evidence for seafloor spreading.

2BC2C623ABE748B6AAD74A9EF4369BE4.description: Create models that demonstrate different types of orogeny resulting from plate tectonics. Show how the interactions between oceanic and continental plates create different geological features (such as volcanic island arcs or high altitude plateaus) depending on what types of plates are involved in the motions along different plate boundaries.

40FBE990F7984007A6B851B4AA0AA435.description: I can explain each geologic feature found at specific plate boundaries.

1A1D7D1E54404CAC8AB64C7D40EF72FC.description: I can name and describe the major plate boundaries.

7017ED86088B417EB999AFF4C2A0AD2C.description: I can provide evidence for plate movement.

9FC36E3AD406469C9A8A20F811888179.description: I can relate continental drift to plate tectonics

DB3C2C4DB7DA4BCC987036C5D8EF2B45.description: Construct a diagram and explanation showing the convection of Earth's mantle and its impact on the movements of tectonic plates. Explain how the decay of radioactive isotopes and residual energy from Earth's original formation provide the heat to fuel this convective process, which, along with ridge push and slab pull, drive the movements of tectonic plates.

B6B4E045245143F18B66EDB8AB0016DD.description: I can create a timeline to show the development of modern plate tectonic theory from historical concepts

BE4CAB9901854BC386336B4C7274BB7F.description: Create a timeline to show the development of modern tectonic plate theory. Identify and explain how the evidence from the theory of continental drift, seafloor spreading, and paleomagnetism built upon each other to support tectonic plate theory.

1DD2EE7DE1F443A3BEB16F5DDE1540C9.description: I can explain how the EM field impacts biological life and technological processes on Earth.

9EDEDBFB8B7C4AFA816064C908203BF1.description: I can relate the motion of the outer core to the EM field around the earth.

751ABB4ACA8C465A91968CA4D031C4CF.description: Explain how Earth's fluid outer core creates the magnetosphere and how this helps protect both humans and technology (such as satellites) from solar winds.

412B6A3A4BB744A4A64E3EB3216A57D7.description: I can create a diagram or model to identify and describe the major layers of the Earth.

87966311BFD645FF9F980F9F30469EB9.description: I can differentiate between chemical and physical layers of the Earth

9B26B3022776486CBC93CB50979B4D38.description: I can identify properties of the astheno- and lithosphere.

F6BDFAB907DA4624977BFE1DB4856AF8.description: I can describe the 3 events that gave rise to Earth's heat.

2B2F215288A84225B73B68958F632753.description: Construct a diagram or model that identifies and describes the physical and chemical properties of the crust, mantle, outer core, and inner core of Earth.

7BF9062A202E4240B115AE0544FE246A.description: I can differentiate between evaporites and biochemical formations.

4934F84D2C4B497FBCD3A2D1D934BF05.description: I can create a timeline of the major geologic events that have created the bedrock of Indiana.

51D2BF908B864018BE68CEAD9AF73A1E.description: I can draw conclusions to determine the relative age of Indiana bedrock using superposition of layers and index fossils.

C1203A6037204218A21C26A4AD10A366.description: I can determine the proper dating type for organic or inorganic rock formations.

33C13ECEA8F3404D858DE689AB9D6A1C.description: I can differentiate between relative vs absolute dating.

7C76A9DBF46A496EB2EC1265C54356A7.description: I can describe processes to change between each rock type.

4503315BDD89422BB8466012A1B870EE.description: I can create a rock cycle flow chart

3B4F6D1B7C6C41A59A2D390B68D33ACE.description: I can define the rock cycle.

D87B5AFC326C40E897BF65BD511896DD.description: Create a rock cycle flowchart or diagram that demonstrates the processes involved in the formation, breakdown, and reformation of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rock. Show how each type can melt and reform igneous rock, undergo the various metamorphic processes, and undergo physical and chemical weathering to form sedimentary rock.

3B4953A45307486CAB05121CF4220DB3.description: I can describe how minerals make up rocks.

3C80E8D5C07F425CB2BEC68B69269DD9.description: I can perform chemical tests to identify minerals.

05524B21960942128DF86AED41C19AF6.description: I can perform physical tests to identify minerals.

25137041332C4CDC97D0DA8CD043B52A.description: I can organize minerals into chemical groups or compounds.

2B58CA3B38674A098E6706D1E842887B.description: I can use the five characteristics of minerals to identify a mineral sample.

7B3802C8EF19427FA7C7DE659E159380.description: I can describe the five characterstics of a mineral.

9930C4949B6641CF89C93BB4BF5A3688.description: Construct a lab to analyze minerals based on their physical and chemical properties. Explain how rocks may contain many minerals, one mineral, or no minerals, and minerals can be made of either single elements (such as gold) or compounds (such as silicates).

8F126973BB424C9D805B390BF4E80A15.description: Constructing explanations (for science) and designing solutions (for engineering)

0DFC8D8B95F843D6877E6627458F70C5.description: Developing and using models and tools

9139F263AF1D4E98BBF5CDC93FCB2F49.description: Posing questions (for science) and defining problems (for engineering)
